channel.title: KCRW's Art Talk
channel.itunes:author: Edward Goldman
channel.description:
Art reviews, news and announcements from Edward Goldman.

Edward Goldman is an art consultant for private and corporate collectors. Email him at edwardgoldman@earthlink.net. Or call him at 310-314-4660 ext 280.
channel.itunes:subtitle: Insightful commentary on LA's art scene.
channel.itunes:summary:
Art reviews, news and announcements from Edward Goldman.

Edward Goldman is an art consultant for private and corporate collectors. Email him at edwardgoldman@earthlink.net. Or call him at 310-314-4660 ext 280.

item.title: In Memory of Kathy Reges
item.itunes:author: Edward Goldman
item.description: Los Angeles has been shaped by untold contributions of millions of people. Some sad events of recent days have made me think of those special people who left a wonderful and lasting legacy on our city of angels.
item.itunes:subtitle: Los Angeles has been shaped by untold contributions of millions of people. Some sad events of recent days have made me think of those special people who left a wonderful and lasting legacy on our city of angels.
item.itunes:summary: Los Angeles has been shaped by untold contributions of millions of people. Some sad events of recent days have made me think of those special people who left a wonderful and lasting legacy on our city of angels.

item.title: L.A. Embarrassment of Riches
item.itunes:author: Edward Goldman
item.description: From King Tut's archaeological artifacts and 17th century paintings by Rembrandt and Ruisdael to early 20th century photographs by Hungarian born Andr- Kert-sz and to graffiti inspired American art by Jean-Michel Basquiat -- these hot summer months, love it or hate it, Los Angeles is the place to be for those who like their art to be all over the map.
item.itunes:subtitle: From King Tut's archaeological artifacts and 17th century paintings by Rembrandt and Ruisdael to early 20th century photographs by Hungarian born Andr- Kert-sz and to graffiti inspired American art by Jean-Michel Basquiat -- these hot summer months, love it or hate it, Los Angeles is the place to be for those who like their art to be all over the map.
item.itunes:summary: From King Tut's archaeological artifacts and 17th century paintings by Rembrandt and Ruisdael to early 20th century photographs by Hungarian born Andr- Kert-sz and to graffiti inspired American art by Jean-Michel Basquiat -- these hot summer months, love it or hate it, Los Angeles is the place to be for those who like their art to be all over the map.

item.title: The Comeuppance Smart Critic
item.itunes:author: Edward Goldman
item.description: My late mother used to tell me affectionately, "Edward, you are smart," but then she would say, "But not enough." Truth be told, there were a number of occasions of late where she proved to be right, but we're talking here about art, not my personal life---aren't we?
item.itunes:subtitle: My late mother used to tell me affectionately, "Edward, you are smart," but then she would say, "But not enough." Truth be told, there were a number of occasions of late where she proved to be right, but we're talking here about art, not my personal life---aren't we?
item.itunes:summary: My late mother used to tell me affectionately, "Edward, you are smart," but then she would say, "But not enough." Truth be told, there were a number of occasions of late where she proved to be right, but we're talking here about art, not my personal life---aren't we?

item.title: Does Tim Hawkinson Have Multiple Personalities?
item.itunes:author: Edward Goldman
item.description: The opening of Tim Hawkinson's exhibition at LACMA a couple of weeks ago turned into an event memorable not only as a chance to celebrate the work of one of the most inventive artists working today, but also an occasion to observe a crowd behaving in a most unusual way: with goofy smiles on their faces, adult men and women were giggling or intently staring in total disbelief. And let me admit for the record that, as for myself, I was guilty on both counts.
item.itunes:subtitle: The opening of Tim Hawkinson's exhibition at LACMA a couple of weeks ago turned into an event memorable not only as a chance to celebrate the work of one of the most inventive artists working today, but also an occasion to observe a crowd behaving in a most unusual way: with goofy smiles on their faces, adult men and women were giggling or intently staring in total disbelief. And let me admit for the record that, as for myself, I was guilty on both counts.

And let me admit for the record that, as for myself, I was guilty on both counts.

item.title: The Explosion of New Museums: Too Much of a Good Thing?
item.itunes:author: Edward Goldman
item.description: If you've lived long enough to make it around the block once or twice, then you know that it's possible to have too much of a good thing. For example, I would never complain that there are too many museums in Rome or in Paris. But I would be wary of a phenomenon of a hundred new museums springing up in a short period of time in one country...
item.itunes:subtitle: If you've lived long enough to make it around the block once or twice, then you know that it's possible to have too much of a good thing. For example, I would never complain that there are too many museums in Rome or in Paris. But I would be wary of a phenomenon of a hundred new museums springing up in a short period of time in one country...

For example, I would never complain that there are too many museums in Rome or in Paris. But I would be wary of a phenomenon of a hundred new museums springing up in a short period of time in one country...

item.title: King Tut: First Time's A Charm, The Second Time A Travesty
item.itunes:author: Edward Goldman
item.description: So much has been said and written about the whirlwind King Tut exhibition--launched last week here at LACMA--that I hesitated initially to talk about it. I thought, &quotWhy add to all this white noise?&quot But after the totally disagreeable experience of attending the gala opening, followed, a few days later, by walking through the exhibition with the curator, I am filled with conflicting emotions.
item.itunes:subtitle: So much has been said and written about the whirlwind King Tut exhibition--launched last week here at LACMA--that I hesitated initially to talk about it.
